description: K-means is a popular unsupervised machine learning algorithm used for clustering data into distinct groups based on similarity. It partitions the dataset into K predefined clusters, where each data point belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean.

common_types.name: Standard K-means
common_types.description: The basic version of the k-means algorithm, where the number of clusters (K) is predefined, and the algorithm iteratively refines the clusters based on the centroids.

common_types.name: K-medoids
common_types.description: A variant of k-means that uses actual data points (medoids) as cluster centers instead of means, making it more robust to noise and outliers.

common_types.name: Fuzzy K-means
common_types.description: A soft clustering method where each data point can belong to multiple clusters with varying degrees of membership, rather than being assigned to a single cluster.

common_types.name: Mini-batch K-means
common_types.description: An optimized version of k-means that processes small random batches of data to improve efficiency and scalability for large datasets.

visualization_techniques.description: Visualizes the clustering of data points in a two-dimensional space, with different colors representing different clusters.
Used to determine the optimal number of clusters by plotting the sum of squared distances from each point to its assigned cluster center against the number of clusters.
Displays the silhouette score of each data point, providing insight into the appropriateness of the clustering and the separation between clusters.
A tree-like diagram that illustrates the arrangement of clusters formed at different levels of similarity, often used in hierarchical clustering.

applications: Customer segmentation for targeted marketing strategies.
Image compression by grouping similar pixel values.
Anomaly detection in network security by identifying unusual patterns.
Document clustering to organize and categorize large sets of text data.
